objdescid.origination: William Blake author, inventor, delineator, etcher, printer, colorist

objinfo.numberobj: 17 This copy does not contain Bentley Plate 3.
objinfo.objorder: Bentley Plates 1-2, 4-18 The inscriptions added to many of the plates, plus the writing on the verso of the title page (Object 2, Bentley Plate 2), are available as Supplemental Views; see the note on Medium, below.
objinfo.objsize: ranging between 23.9 x 17.3 cm. and 23.1 x 16.4 cm.
objinfo.numberleaves: 11 Objects 1 and 2 (Bentley Plates 1 and 2) are printed on the rectos of single leaves; the other plates are printed recto/verso.
objinfo.medium:
Relief and white-line etching with color printing and hand coloring. Objects 1, 3-11, 13-15, 17 (Bentley Plates 1, 4-12, 14-16, 18) and the verso of Object 2 (Bentley Plate 2) bear pen and ink inscriptions. Objects 7-9, 13, 15, 17 (Bentley Plates 8-10, 14, 16, 18) also bear brief pencil inscriptions.
The pen and ink inscriptions, attributed by Bentley (page 159) and others to George Cumberland, are available as Supplemental Views in the Archive for each object on which they appear. Most are quoted from Edward Bysshe, *The Art of English Poetry* , a popular and often reprinted anthology of English verse, arranged by subject and first published in 1702. Shared textual variants indicate that Bysshe was the source, as first pointed out in S. Foster Damon, *William Blake: His Philosophy and Symbols* (1924), pages 347-51. We have surveyed several editions of Bysshe through the ninth (1762), the last edition known to us that was published prior to the etching of *Europe a Prophecy* . The pencil inscriptions, also available as Supplemental Views, would appear to have been written in a hand different from the pen and ink inscriptions and may be of a later date. The leaves are stamped on their rectos with a British Museum collection mark which, on some objects, extends into the image.
objinfo.inkcolor: Objects 7-8 (Bentley Plates 8-9) in brown, all other objects in blue-green. The manuscript ink (see the note on Medium, above) is now dark brown.
objinfo.watermark: I Taylor The watermark appears only on the leaves bearing Objects 3-4 and 13-14 (Bentley Plates 4-5 and 14-15).
objinfo.pennednumbers: 1-15 The penned numbers appear on Objects 3-17 (Bentley Plates 4-18). The odd numbers appear top right, the even numbers top left.
objinfo.binding: mounted in heavy paper mats bound in red morocco with *Visions of the Daughters of Albion* Copy A. Both works were formerly bound together in half green morocco. The present binding was created in 1969.

provenance.name: British Museum, Department of Prints and Drawings
provenance.note: Acquired, probably directly from Blake in 1796, by Ozias Humphry; apparently lent by Humphry to George Cumberland, who added the pen and ink inscriptions; bequeathed by Humphry to his son, William Upcott, in 1810; sold after Upcott's death at Evans, the London auction house, 15 June 1846, lot 277, with *The Large Book of Designs* Copy A and *The Small Book of Designs* Copy A "inserted," and with *America a Prophecy* Copy H in the same lot (£7.2s.6d. to the dealer R. H. Evans); possibly acquired by Francis Turner Palgrave; acquired by the British Museum on 25 June 1859.

illustration.illusobjdesc: An old, nude, but muscular man with long hair and beard squats within a circle, perhaps meant to represent the disc of the sun. His hair and beard extend horizontally to the left, as though blown by a strong wind from right to left. His left leg is bent at the knee, with both left knee and left foot prominent. His right leg is kneeling, with the lower leg bent back, on the edge of the circle. He is hunched over and looks down or has his eyes closed; his left arm is extended down. He holds a pair of dividers or compasses in his left hand, with his forefinger spread away from his other fingers. Indications of a robe or some sort of drapery appear just right of the figure's left foot. Beams of light emanate from the circle, surrounded by clouds except where the man's arm extends downward. The figure is very probably Urizen in the act of creating and/or circumscribing the material universe. This design, perhaps Blake's most famous, has also been titled by critics "The Ancient of Days" and "God Creating the Universe."

The figure kneels within a circle or sphere, perhaps the sun, from which beams of light emanate.
The figure holds dividers or compasses.
The figure and the disc in which he squats are surrounded by clouds except where his left arm descends.
The horizontal position of the figure's hair and beard suggest a strong wind blowing from right to left.

desc.objtitle:
EUROPE a PROPHECY,
Object 1 full view including inscriptions (Bentley 1, Erdman i, Keynes i)

,
Object 1 bottom inscription (Bentley 1, Erdman i, Keynes i)

objnote.p: This pen and ink inscription appears below the image. The lines are quoted from John Milton, *Paradise Lost* (1667), Book 7, lines 224-31. We have not been able to find these lines in the editions of Edward Bysshe, *The Art of English Poetry* , we have surveyed.

lg.l: In his hand, he took, the Golden Compasses, prepared
In Gods eternal store, to circumscribe
This Universe, and all created things.

One foot he
center'd centered, and the other
turn'd turned,
Round through the vast profundity obscure,
And said, thus far extend, thus far thy bounds

This be thy just circumference, O World!
Bentley reads "world" for "World" ( *Writings* volume 1, page 708).
Milton

illustration.illusobjdesc: The pictorial image is treated as a full-plate design. A giant snake is coiled just above the imprint. Its upper body reaches upward in two loops, suggesting a spiral, with its head facing to the right. The small crest on top of its head in other copies is only hinted at here. Its mouth is open, and its long forked tongue is prominent. Its body extends beyond the lower right margin of the plate and then returns under the imprint, with its tail ending below "Blake" (line 5) in the imprint. The slightly mottled color printing of the snake's body suggests scales. Below the two large coils of its lower body and right of "Lambeth" (line 4) in the imprint are some vegetative forms, perhaps leaves. The washes behind the snake's coils suggest sky, possibly with clouds, hills, or mountains. The snake has been identified as the serpent-form of Orc, the personification of revolutionary energy.

component.illusobjdesc: A giant snake is coiled just above the imprint. Its upper body reaches upward in two loops, suggesting a spiral, with its head facing to the right. Its body extends beyond the lower right margin of the plate and then returns under the imprint, with its tail ending below "Blake" (line 5) in the imprint. The slightly mottled color printing of the snake's body suggests scales. The snake has been identified as the serpent-form of Orc, the personification of revolutionary energy.
Below the two large coils of the snake's lower body and right of "Lambeth" (line 4) in the imprint are some vegetative forms, perhaps leaves. There may be more such vegetative forms on the left.
Washes behind the snake's coils suggest sky, possibly with clouds, hills, or distant mountains directly behind and to the right of the coils.

a

Printed by Will: Blake: 1794 In Copy D, the word "Printed" is very faint.

desc.objtitle:
,
Object 2 verso inscription (Bentley 2, Erdman ii, Keynes ii)

objnote.p: This pen and ink inscription is written on the verso of Object 2 (Bentley Plate 2), the title page. It refers to Object 3 (Bentley Plate 4), which it faces. The lines are quoted from Ann Radcliffe, The Mysteries of Udolpho (1794), volume 3, chapter 7. These lines do not appear in Edward Bysshe, *The Art of English Poetry* , for we have found no edition of Bysshe published later than 1762 other than reprints of earlier editions.

lg.l:
The Pilgrim, by Ann
Radcliff Radcliffe.

Slow
oe'r overthe
Apannine Apanninewith bleeding feet,
"Apannine" was rewritten once or twice. Bentley reads "Apinine" for "Apannine"( *Writings* volume 1, page 708).

A Patient Pilgrim wound his lonely way,
Bentley reads "patient" for "Patient" ( *Writings* volume 1, page 708).

To deck the Lady of Loretto's seat,
Bentley reads "Lorretto's" for "Loretto's" ( *Writings* volume 1, page 708).
With all the little wealth his zeal could pay.
From mountain tops cold died the evening ray,

And
stretch't stretchedin twilight slept the vale below,
Bentley reads "stretch'd" for "stretch't" ( *Writings* volume 1, page 708).
And now the last last purple streaks of day "last last": i.e., presumably, a slip for "last".

Along the melancholy
w West fade slow.

High
o'er overhis head the restless Pines complain,

As on their summits rolls the
breze breezeof night
Bentley reads "breeze" for "breze" ( *Writings* volume 1, page 708).

Beneath, the
hoarsestream chides the rocks in vain, The word "hoarse" was written over a word that has been washed out and is now illegible.
The Pilgrim pauses on the dizzy heights,
Then to the vale his cautious steps he prest,

For there a Hermits Cross was dimly seen
Bentley reads "cross" for "Cross" ( *Writings* volume 1, page 708).
Cresting the rock, and there his limbs might rest,

(
cheerd cheeredin the good mans cave by faggot sheen).
On leafy beds, nor guile his sleep molest,

Unhappy
l Luke! he trusts a treacherous clue!
Behind the Cliff the lurking Robber stood,

No friendly moon his Giant shadow threw,
Bentley reads "the" for "his" ( *Writings* volume 1, page 708).
Athwart the road, to save the Pilgrims blood;
On as he went a vesper hymn he sang,
The Hymn that nightly soothed him to repose;
Fierce on his harmless prey thae Ruffian sprang,
The Pilgrim bleeds to death, his eyelids close,
Yet his meek spirit knew no vengeful care,

But dying for his
Mur
l d 'rer Murderer breathed a sainted
prayr prayer!

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two figures appear in the landscape above the text. A nude male sits crouching in a contracted posture within a cave surrounded at its mouth with large stones. His legs are drawn up and his legs crossed at the ankles. He faces to the left, toward the other figure. His left arm is bent at the elbow, with his forearm and index finger on his left hand pointing up. He grasps a knife or dagger in his right hand. He may be an assassin, contemplating the murder of the figure to the left. This figure on the left is a youthful male wearing tights, a hat, a bundle or backpack on his back, and belts over his chest. He strides forward and to the left. He faces left and holds a walking-stick in his right hand. His left arm is bent at the elbow, with his left forearm and hand behind his back. He is probably one of Blake's representations of a traveler. Below his feet is a path or road. Right and left of this walking figure is some undifferentiated vegetation, perhaps the leaves of trees; the vegetation is particularly leafy above the cave with the assassin and right of the traveler's right foot.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude male sits crouching in a contracted posture within a cave surrounded at its mouth with large stones. His legs are drawn up and his legs crossed at the ankles. He faces to the left, toward the other figure. His left arm is bent at the elbow, with his forearm and index finger on his left hand pointing up. He grasps a knife or dagger in his right hand. His mouth is drawn into an evil smile. He may be an assassin, contemplating the murder of the figure to the left.

A youthful male wearing tights, a hat, a bundle or backpack on his back, and belts over his chest, strides forward and to the left. He faces left and holds a walking-stick in his right hand. His left arm is bent at the elbow, with his left forearm and hand behind his back. He is probably one of Blake's representations of a traveler.
The figure with a dagger crouches within a cave formed of large stones.
The walking figure strides forward on a road or path.

Vegetation, perhaps the leaves of trees, fills the area behind the walking figure; there is other leafy vegetation above the cave in which the crouching figure sits and right of the traveler's right foot.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Below the text, we see a human (and apparently male) head, facing directly at us, with a pained or despairing expression. This head seems to be surrounded tightly by the figure's arms and snake-like drapery. The ends of this drapery curve over the head and to the left, where it forms two loops. The figure seems to be flying on its large, bat-like wings. At least ten birds fly near the figure, above him and below and to the right of his left wing. Further to the right, a male figure, nude or possibly wearing tights, falls head-first. His legs are bent at the knees, with the left leg drawn up near his chest. His arms are raised over his head and bent at the elbows with his hands behind his head. A large weight is attached to his hands or arms, apparently with a single link of a chain that disappears behind his head (because attached to his hands?). This weight apparently pulls him downwards.

component.illusobjdesc: Below the text, we see a human (and apparently male) head, facing directly at us, with a pained or despairing expression. This head seems to be surrounded tightly by the figure's arms and snake-like drapery. The ends of this drapery curve over the head and to the left, where it forms two loops. The figure seems to be flying on its large, bat-like wings.

A male figure, nude or possibly wearing tights, falls head-first. His legs are bent at the knees, with the left leg drawn up near his chest. His arms are raised over his head and bent at the elbows with his hands behind his head. A large weight is attached to his arms or hands, apparently with a single link of a chain that disappears behind his head (because attached to his hands?). This weight apparently pulls him downwards.
A large weight is attached to the arms or hands of the descending figure, apparently with a single link of a chain that disappears behind his head (because attached to his hands?).
At least ten birds fly near the bat-winged figure, above him and below and to the right of his left wing.

illustration.illusobjdesc: There is a good deal of interlinear decoration, particularly in the margins of the text. Most consists of vines and leaves, but there are also a few animals. The first letter of the first word in line 3 twists into a spiral vine on the left; it descends with one further loop in the left margin to line 11. A long, wavy vine extends between lines 5 and 6. On it is a long-legged spider, just above "other sons" in line 6. Further to the left, under the first word of line 5, is a small form that may be a fly, moth, or butterfly. A vine trails downward from this same first word ("And") in line 5. Just left of the beginning of line 14 is a flying creature, perhaps an insect of some sort. In the bottom left corner of the plate, a vine descends from the first letter of the first word in the last line of text (line 17). In the right margin, another branch of the vine extending between lines 5 and 6 descends from the design above the text all the way to the lower margin. It bears loops, at least two types of leaves, and perhaps some fruit or flowers. A butterfly sits on the upper reaches of this vine (opposite line 5); a worm or caterpillar inches its way across the upper reaches of a large, slender leaf opposite the space between lines 9 and 10; and there may be another insect resting on a leaf just to the left of the worm or caterpillar. Other branches of this vine extend above the falling figure and intertwine with the large leaf to the right of this same figure. To the right are two flying birds. A separate vine with spiky leaves twists right of lines 6 and 7, growing from the "d" in "thunder." Below one of its tendrils, and just to the right of line 9, is a flying insect, perhaps a beetle or fly. A somewhat jagged vine extends horizontally following line 8; to the right is another vine, growing from the top of the second letter of "of" in line 9.

component.illusobjdesc: A butterfly sits on the upper reaches of the vine in the far right margin, right of the space between lines 5 and 6 of the text.
A worm (perhaps an inch worm) or caterpillar rises above the large vine right of the space between lines 9 and 10.
There may be a small insect of some sort resting on the large vine right of the space between lines 9 and 10, just to the left of the worm or caterpillar.
Far to the right of lines 15-16, between the long leaves and the edge of the plate, are two flying birds.
The first letter of the first word, line 3 of the text, twists into a spiral vine on the left. It extends with one further loop in the left margin to line 11.
A long vine—a branch of the main vine in the right margin—extends horizontally between lines 5 and 6 of the text.
A vine trails downward from the first word ("And") in line 5.
In the bottom left corner of the plate, a vine descends from the first letter of the first word in the last line of text (line 17).

In the right margin of the text, a loopy vine with leaves of at least two types (including very long ones) and perhaps flowers and/or fruit descends from the design above the text all the way to the lower margin. A branch with spiky leaves extends above the falling figure; another branch is intertwined with the long leaf right of this figure.
A vine with three tendrils or branches and perhaps some spiky leaves twists right of lines 6 and 7 of the text, growing from the "d" in "thunder."
A somewhat jagged vine extends horizontally following line 8 of the text; to the right is another vine, growing from the top of the second letter of "of" in line 9.
On the long vine running between lines 5 and 6 of the text is a long-legged spider, just above "other sons" in line 6.
Under the first word of line 5 of the text is a small form that may be a fly, moth, or butterfly.
To the left of the beginning of line 14 in the text is a flying creature, perhaps an insect of some sort.
To the right of line 9 of the text is a flying insect, perhaps a beetle or fly.

lg.l: The nameless shadowy female rose from out the breast of Orc:
Her snaky hair brandishing in the winds of Enitharmon:
And thus her voice arose.
O mother Enitharmon wilt thou bring forth other sons?
To cause my name to vanish, that my place may not be found.
For I am faint with travel!
Like the dark cloud disburdend in the day of dismal thunder.
My roots are brandish'd in the heavens, my fruits in earth beneath
Surge, foam, and labour into life, first born & first consum'd!
Consumed and consuming!
Then why shouldst thou accursed mother bring me into life?
I wrap my turban of thick clouds around my lab'ring head:
And fold the sheety waters as a mantle round my limbs.
Yet the red sun and moon,
And all the overflowing stars rain down prolific pains.

desc.objtitle:
,
Object 3 full view including inscriptions (Bentley 4, Erdman 1, Keynes 1)

objnote.p: These inscriptions appear above the image. The first line is written in pen and ink; the second line, in pencil, may have been written by a different hand; the third line is written in pen and ink by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although containing considerable text, the plate is treated as a full-page design showing four nude males in the sky. The two text areas are shaped like clouds. Upper right, we see a figure from behind with his left leg bent and his left foot poised on a cloud extending down and to the left. His right leg is extended; he may be rising. We do not see his arms, but his hands clutch his head. This gesture suggests despair. His hair may be curly. Below is a group of three wrestling figures, all nude and bald. The central figure has his legs spread, with his left leg extended and his right bent at the knee with his right foot below his groin. He looks down and to the right. With his right arm he grasps another bald nude around the neck, apparently in an attempt to strangle him. This central figure's left arm is bent at the elbow and he grasps the neck of another bald nude with his left hand. The figure on the left has his legs spread and bent at the knees. He looks up and to the right and tries, with both hands, to release the central male's arm from around his neck. The wrestler on the right has his legs spread, with his left leg extended vertically and his right leg bent at the knee. His arms are bent back over his shoulders and grasp the left leg of the central male. All three figures have caricature-like facial expressions suggesting fear and pain (figures right and left) or desperation and cruelty (central figure). The background behind the wrestlers is formed of dark and perhaps stormy clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: Upper right, we see a nude from behind with his left leg bent and his left foot poised on a cloud extending down and to the left. His right leg is extended; he may be rising. We do not see his arms, but his hands clutch his head. This gesture suggests despair. His hair may be curly.
A group of three wrestlers, all nude and bald males, hovers in front of dark clouds.

The central bald, nude, and muscular male in the group of three wrestlers hovering in the sky has his legs spread, with his left leg extended and his right bent at the knee with his right foot below his groin. He looks down and to the right. With his right arm he grasps another bald nude around the neck, apparently in an attempt to strangle him. The central figure's left arm is bent at the elbow and he grasps the neck of another bald nude with his left hand. He may be smiling.

The figure on the left in the group of three nude and bald male wrestlers hovering in the sky has his legs spread and bent at the knees. He looks up and to the right and tries, with both hands, to release the central male's arm from around his neck. His mouth is slightly open, and his face expresses pain and terror.

The wrestler on the right in the group of three nude and bald males has his legs spread, with his left leg extended vertically and his right leg bent at the knee. His arms are bent back over his shoulders and grasp the left leg of the central male. His head is bent back as he is being strangled, and his mouth is slightly open; his face expresses pain and terror.

The two text areas are shaped like, and perhaps are supposed to represent, clouds. These clouds extend to the right margin below the figure upper right. Dark clouds appear below the text, where the wrestling figures are backed by a dark and perhaps stormy sky.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Several vegetative and avian motifs decorate the text. A vine twists into the left margin from the bottom of the first letter of the first word in line 3. A similar vine connects the last letter of "bind" and the second letter of the next word ("the") in line 14. A spiky vine with tendrils or branches hovers above "my voice" in line 17. The descender of "my" in this same line becomes a twisting vine. Two birds, the one on the left barely visible, fly above "vig'rous progeny" in line 9, a flock of four birds flies right of line 12, a single bird soars over "infinite with" in line 14, and a flock of three birds follows line 16.

component.illusobjdesc: Two birds, the one on the left barely visible, fly above "vig'rous progeny" in line 9 of the text, a flock of four birds flies right of line 12, a single bird soars over "infinite with" in line 14, and a flock of three birds follows line 16.
A vine twists into the left margin from the bottom of the first letter of the first word in line 3 of the text.
A vine connects the last letter of "bind" and the second letter of the next word ("the") in line 14 of the text.
A spiky vine with tendrils or branches hovers above "my voice" in line 17 of the text. The descender of "my" in this same line becomes a twisting vine.

lg.l: Unwilling I look up to heaven! unwilling count the stars.
Sitting in fathomless abyss of my immortal shrine.
I sieze their burning power
And bring forth howling terrors, all devouring fiery kings.
Devouring & devouréd roaming on dark and desolate mountains
In forests of eternal death, shrieking in hollow trees.
Ah mother Enitharmon!
Stamp not with solid form this vig'rous progeny of fires.
I bring forth from my teeming bosom myriads of flames.
And thou dost stamp them with a signet. then they roam abroad
And leave me void as death:
Ah! I am drown'd in shady woe. and visionary joy.
And who shall bind the infinite with an eternal band?
To compass it with swaddling bands? and who shall cherish it
With milk and honey?
I see it smile & I roll inward & my voice is past.
She ceast & rolld her shady clouds
Into the secret place.

desc.objtitle:
,
Object 4 full view including inscriptions (Bentley 5, Erdman 2, Keynes 2)

objnote.p: This pen and ink inscription appears above the image. The lines of verse, exclusive of the title, are quoted from Samuel Garth, The Dispensary (1699), Book 6, lines 103-06. These lines are printed in Edward Bysshe, *The Art of English Poetry* , under the heading "Winds." The fifth line is written in pen and ink by Blake.

lg.l: Storms, Tempests. &c
He views with horror next the noisy cave

Where with hoarse din
imprisond imprisonedtempests rave

Where
clam'rous clamorousHurricanes attempt their flight
Or whirling in tumultuous Eddies fight.

objnote.p: This pen and ink inscription appears below the image. The lines are quoted from Sir Richard Blackmore, *Prince Arthur* (1695), Book 6. These lines are printed in Edward Bysshe, The Art of English Poetry , under the heading "Storm."

lg.l: This orbs wide frame with the convulsion shakes,

Oft opens in the Storm, and often cracks,
Bentley reads "storm" for "Storm" ( *Writings* volume 1, page 709).

Horror,
a A mazement, and Despair appear,

In all the hideous forms that Mortals fear.
Bentley reads "mortals" for "Mortals" ( *Writings* volume 1, page 709).

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although the plate contains a good deal of text and a great deal of interlinear decoration, the major pictorial motifs—the sky and the two largest figures—constitute a full- plate design. The three text panels are shaped like, and may represent, clouds floating in the sky. The largest figure, hovering horizontally in the air just below the heading, is a gowned female. The hem of her garment forms a snake-like tail. Her body is twisted, facing forward below the waist and facing down above the waist. Her long hair cascades over (and hence obscures) her face. Her arms are bent at the elbows and her hands are clasped behind her head. She has large wings, and thus may be an angel. More specifically, in the context of this poem, she has been identified as Enitharmon, a nature goddess of fallen time and space, and as the "nameless shadowy female" (Plate 3, line 3) who wraps a "turban of thick clouds" around her "lab'ring head" (Plate 3, line 14). Below her cascading hair is a nude, youthful male in a contracted posture. He seems confined by the circle in which he sits. This circle may be meant to represent a globe; it has been described as a comet, although there is no tail. It may be a planet. His legs are bent at the knees and drawn up to his chest; his arms are bent at the elbows with his hands, formed into fists, against his cheeks just below his eyes. He faces forward. Flames surround him within the globe. This may be Orc, the spirit of revolution here confined, the "secret child" (of Enitharmon?) mentioned on the plate (line 5), or one of Enitharmon's "vig'rous progeny of fires" (Plate 4, line 9). The other motifs on this plate, including many human figures, will be treated as interlinear designs.

component.illusobjdesc: The largest figure on the plate, hovering horizontally in the air just below the heading, is a gowned female. Her body is twisted, facing forward below the waist and facing down above the waist. The hem of her garment forms a snake-like tail. Her long hair cascades over (and hence obscures) her face. Her arms are bent at the elbows and her hands are clasped behind her head. She has large wings, and thus may be an angel. More specifically, in the context of this poem, she has been identified as Enitharmon, a nature goddess of fallen time and space, and as the "nameless shadowy female" (Plate 3, line 3) who wraps a "turban of thick clouds" around her "lab'ring head" (Plate 3, line 14).

A nude, youthful male in a very contracted posture sits within a circle. This circle may be meant to represent a globe; it has been described as a comet, although there is no tail. His legs are bent at the knees and drawn up to his chest; his arms are bent at the elbows with his hands, formed into fists, against his cheeks just below his eyes. Flames surround him within the globe. This may be Orc, the spirit of revolution here confined, the "secret child" (of Enitharmon?) mentioned on the plate (line 5), or one of Enitharmon's "vig'rous progeny of fires" (Plate 4, line 9).

A figure squats or sits within a circle which may be meant to represent a globe. It has been described as a comet, although there is no tail. Hence, this may be a planet. Flames surround the figure within the globe.
The three text panels are shaped like, and may be intended to represent, clouds.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The heading is surrounded by several figures and vegetative motifs. The figures, particularly the larger ones, may be the "sons & daughters" (line 9) of Enitharmon referred to on the plate. The lower left corner of "A" (in "A / PROPHECY" [lines 2-3]) grows into a long vine with branches. Standing on this vine, near the left foot of the letter, is a human figure facing forward. His or her arms, raised vertically, grow into limbs of a tree that bend downwards, as with a willow. The motif suggests the classical myth of Daphne and her vegetating metamorphosis. This parallel suggests that the figure is female. On the right diagonal of the "A" are three leaves. To the left of the "A" and slightly below it is a male(?) embracing a female. Both hover in the air, with the male on the right and facing to the left. The male is nude; the woman is gowned and has a long, snake-like tail of drapery extending from her right leg. The man's body is twisted into a curve, seen from behind. His left arm is raised horizontally and embraces the woman's waist. His right leg is extended horizontally. We also see the woman from behind, with her body twisted into a curve matching the man's. Both her arms are raised horizontally, with her head facing down. These gestures suggest that she is trying to escape from the man. In contrast, the couple right of the letter "A" is embracing mutually and appear to be kissing. The winged male(?), possibly an angel, hovers horizontally in the air, with his arms raised at 45 degrees to embrace the woman(?) who hovers vertically. She too is winged and may be an angel. Her legs are bent back and her arms raised at 135 degrees to embrace her companion. He faces down and to the left; she faces up and to the right. Below the "A" is a hunched over, and apparently gowned, figure facing to the left. This extremely contracted figure, with his or her upper body and head bent down to touch the upper legs, sits on a cloud outline. Other cloud outlines extend to the upper right and below "PROPHECY" in the heading. On the right, below a cloud outline and above the last letter of "PROPHECY," two nude figures seen from behind soar in the sky, left arms raised horizontally and right arms raised at 135 degrees. The letters of "PROPHECY" are well decorated with eight human figures and vines. Proceeding from left to right, these include a vine with leaves or lily-like flowers intertwined with the first letter and extending to the second. A small standing figure holds the vertical of the first "P." Another figure stands on the foot of the vertical of the "R" and faces to the left with arms raised vertically. Above this figure is a small form that may be a descending child or infant, arms stretched downward toward the adult. The right foot of the "R" bears a very small seated figure, hunched over and facing to the right. The letter "O" has two vines with lily-like flowers. Standing within the "O" is a figure facing forward and with left arm raised horizontally to hold a shepherd's crook. To the right of this shepherd is a small flock of sheep. Three vines, or perhaps flames, spring from the foot of the second "P." A vine, perhaps with a few leaves, is intertwined with the next three letters ("HEC"). The final vine in this group springs from the foot of the final letter and forms a spiral above and to the right of the letter. This "Y" also bears three human figures. One, seen from behind and with legs spread and arms raised vertically, seems to be climbing, with the right foot on the foot of the "Y" and the left foot on the "C." Above, standing on the top left end of the "Y," is a figure. Finally, the first bend in the vine growing from the right side of the final letter bears a seated figure facing right, with back slightly hunched over and right arm extended to the right knee. This figure holds a book or tablet and is probably reading. Two flames, or perhaps a flame-like plant, spring from the foot of the "Y" on its right side.

component.illusobjdesc: The human figures surrounding the heading, particularly the four largest figures, may be the "sons & daughters" (line 9) of Enitharmon referred to on the plate.

Standing on the vine springing from the lower left of the letter "A," near the left foot of the letter, is a human figure facing forward. His or her arms, raised vertically, grow into limbs of a tree that bend downwards, as with a willow. The motif suggests the classical myth of Daphne and her vegetating metamorphosis. This parallel suggests that the figure is female.

Below and left of the "A" in the title (line 2), a nude male(?), hovering in the air, embraces a female with his left arm around her waist. We see him from behind, but his body is twisted into a curve. His hair is long; his right leg is extended horizontally to the left. He faces left.

Below and left of the "A" in the title (line 2), a gowned female with long hair, facing down and to the left, hovers in the air. She is embraced around the waist by the male(?) to the right. We see her from behind, with her body twisted into a curve like the male's. A long, snake-like tail of drapery extends from her right leg. Her arms are raised horizontally to the right. This gesture, as well as her head position, suggest that she is trying to flee from the male.

Right of the "A" in the title (line 2), a nude male(?) hovers horizontally and reaches down, with his arms at 45 degrees, to embrace the female(?) below and to the left. His large wings suggest he may be an angel. He faces down and to the left and may be kissing the female. His hair may be curly.

Right of the "A" in the title (line 2), a nude female(?) hovers in the air. Her large wings suggest she may be an angel. She reaches up with her arms raised at 135 degrees arms to embrace the male(?) hovering horizontally to the right. Her legs are slightly bent. She faces up and to the right and may be kissing the male.

Below the "A" of the heading (line 2) is a hunched over, and apparently gowned, figure facing to the left. This extremely contracted figure, with his or her upper body and head bent down to touch the upper legs, sits on a cloud outline.

A small figure holds the vertical of the first letter of "PROPHECY" (line 3) in the heading. The figure reaches up with both arms and may be climbing. The figure probably faces forward or to the right. Although anatomically impossible, the object below the base of the letter may be the figure's dangling right(?) leg.
A small figure stands, facing left, on the foot of the letter "R" in "PROPHECY" (line 3). The figure, probably male, has his arms raised vertically, perhaps to catch the small figure above.

Just above the figure standing on the left foot of the letter "R" in "PROPHECY" (line 3) is a very small human form, probably a child or infant. This tiny figure descends head-first toward the adult below, with arms reaching downward.
A very small figure sits on the right foot of the letter "R" in "PROPHECY" (line 3). The figure faces right and is slightly hunched over.

A figure, probably male, stands within the "O" of "PROPHECY" (line 3). He faces forward with his left arm raised horizontally. He holds a shepherd's crook in his left hand. Given the crook and the flock of sheep to the right, the figure is almost certainly a shepherd.

A figure, probably male and seen from behind, climbs between the "C" and "Y" of "PROPHECY" (line 3). His legs are spread, with his left foot poised on the "C" and his right foot just touching the foot of the "Y." He reaches up vertically with both arms to hold the left diagonal of the "Y."
A very small figure, probably male, stands on top of the left diagonal of the "Y" in "PROPHECY" (line 3). He appears to be walking to the left and may be wearing a knee-length coat.

A small figure, probably gowned and male, sits on the vine extending from the "Y" of "PROPHECY" (line 3). He faces to the right, with his upper body hunched over and his right arm extended at 45 degrees to his knees. He holds, and seems to be reading, a book or tablet.
The small figure sitting on the vine extending from the "Y" of "PROPHECY" (line 3) appears to be holding a book or tablet.

Two figures hover in, or fly through, the air above the "Y" of "PROPHECY" (line 3). Both are probably males, nude and seen from behind. Both have their left arms raised horizontally and their right arms raised at 135 degrees.
A flock of sheep rests within the "O" of "PROPHECY" (line 3), just to the right of their shepherd.
Flames, or perhaps flame-like plants, spring from the foot of the second "P" of "PROPHECY" (line 3) on its right side.
Two flames, or perhaps flame-like plants, spring from the foot of the "Y" of "PROPHECY" (line 3) on its right side.

The outlines of clouds extend above "PROPHECY" (line 3) from the "O" to the upper right corner of the plate; one cloud outline descends between the second "P" and "H" of the word and extends below the word to the "R."
A vine, perhaps with leaves, extends to the left from the left foot of "A" (line 2) in the heading.
The raised arms of the figure standing on the left foot of "A" (line 2) in the heading vegetate into branches that arch downward. This may be a willow.
Three leaves grow from the right diagonal of the "A" (line 2) in the heading.

A vine is intertwined with the first letter of "PROPHECY" (line 3) in the heading. There are leaves or perhaps lily-like flowers at its left end; its right end curls behind the foot of the next letter ("R").

A vine with lily-like flowers is intertwined with the left side of the "O" of "PROPHECY" (line 3). A separate vine, or the other end of the same vine, grows up the right side of the same letter. It too bears lily-like flowers.
A vine with a few leaves and one loop is intertwined with the letters "HEC" of "PROPHECY" (line 3).
A vine, with a spiral upper right, grows from the right side of the foot of "Y" of "PROPHECY" (line 3).

illustration.illusobjdesc: The cloud-like text panel containing lines 4-8 of the text includes three human figures, birds, and some vines. A vine with two loops extends from the first word of line 4 and turns to the right over the first line. On it may be a single leaf or flower between the two loops. To the right of the second loop sits a gowned and apparently female figure. Her body faces to the left, but her head seems to be turned to the right so that we see her head and shoulders from behind. Her left arm extends downward to her knee; her right arm is raised at about 135 degrees and extended to the right. Above her and to the left is a flock of five birds. Two figures hover in the air right of line 4. The gowned figure on the left is probably a female; we see her from behind with one arm raised horizontally and the other at 135 degrees. To the right is a (probably nude and male) figure also hovering and seen from behind. His left leg is extended, his right bent at the knee. He holds, and apparently plays, a horn with one loop in it. To the right of this figure, and above "eternal" in line 6, is a vine. Another vine, with leaves at its lower end, extends from the last letter of the last word ("abodes") in line 8. To the right of this line are two birds, flying upward on extended wings.

component.illusobjdesc: A figure, probably female and wearing a gown, sits on the vine above "deep of" in line 4 of the text. Her body faces to the left, but her head seems to be turned to the right so that we see her head and shoulders from behind. Her left arm extends downward to her knee; her right arm is raised at about 135 degrees.

Two figures hover in the air right of line 4 of the text. The gowned figure on the left is probably a female; we see her from behind with one arm raised horizontally and the other at 135 degrees. The hem of her gown forms a twisting tail.

To the right of line 4, and right of the hovering female figure, is a (probably nude and male) figure also hovering and seen from behind. His left leg is extended, his right bent at the knee. He holds, and apparently plays, a horn with one loop in it.
The figure hovering above "eternal" (line 6) holds, and presumably plays, a horn with one loop in it.
A flock of five birds flies on extended wings above the vine extending horizontally above line 4 of the text.
Two birds fly upwards on extended wings right of line 8 of the text.
A vine with two loops extends from the first word of line 4 of the text and turns to the right over this first line. On it may be a single leaf or flower between the two loops.
A vine curls above "eternal" in line 6 of the text.
A vine, perhaps with leaves at its lower end, extends from the last letter of the last word ("abodes") in line 8 of the text.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Four figures, birds, a cloud outline, and a vine decorate the third cloud-like text panel containing lines 9-18 of the text. A vine loops upward from the first letter of the first word in line 9 and extends above the line to the word "her." A much smaller vine or single leaf grows from the vertical of the last letter in this line. Just above the first word ("Then"), a nude figure (probably male) lies supine on this vine. One leg is extended, the other bent at the knee. The figure faces up; his arms are raised at 135 degrees relative to his body. The figure above may be gowned (note the slight indication of a tail of drapery) and of uncertain gender. This figure's legs are spread and one arm (the left?) is raised vertically. The figure may be rising in the air. To the right, above "Enitharmon" in line 9, is a flying bird. Another two birds fly on extended wings above the last word ("come") in line 13. A cloud outline (or perhaps the surface of the earth?) below and to the right of the birds bears a figure crawling to the right on all fours. Further to the right, another figure, gowned(?) and perhaps female, stands and leans to the left against the cloud outline. Her legs are crossed.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude figure, probably male, lies supine on the vine above the first word ("Then") in line 9 of the text. One leg is extended, the other bent at the knee. The figure faces up; his arms are raised at 135 degrees relative to his body.

A figure, facing left, hovers above the first letter of "Enitharmon" in line 9 of the text. This figure, of uncertain gender, has his or her (left?) arm raised vertically and legs spread. The figure may be gowned (note the suggestion of a tail of drapery) and rising.
A figure crawls to the right on all fours along the cloud outline (or surface of the earth?) above the last word ("rest") in line 14 of the text. The figure may be gowned.

A figure, gowned(?) and probably female, stands and leans to the left against a cloud outline. Her upper body, twisted to the left, is braced against the cloud with her left arm; her legs are crossed.
A bird flies upward on extended wings above the middle letters of "Enitharmon" (and above the vine), line 9 of the text.
Two birds fly on extended wings above the last word ("come") in line 13 of the text.
A vine loops upward from the first letter of the first word in line 9 and extends above the line to the word "her."
The vertical of the final letter of "around," the last word in line 9 of the text, becomes a vine arching over the word. It may terminate in a leaf.

A cloud outline extends from the right margin of the plate and ends above the last word ("come") in line 13 of the text. Perhaps the segment of this line on the left, where a figure is crawling, is meant to represent the surface of the earth rather than a cloud.

lg.l: The deep of winter came:
What time the secret child.
Descended thro' the orient gates of the eternal day;
War ceas'd, & all the troops like shadows fled
to their abodes.
Then Enitharmon saw her sons & daughters rise around.
Like pearly clouds they meet together in the crystal house:
And Los. possessor of the moon. joy'd in the peaceful night;
Thus speaking while his num'rous sons shook their bright fiery wings
Again the night is come
That strong Urthona takes his rest,
And Urizen unloos'd from chains
Glows like a meteor in the distant north
Stretch forth your hands and strike the elemental strings!
Awake the thunders of the deep,

The next four lines are quoted from Alexander Pope's translation of Homer's *Iliad* (1715-20), Book 4, lines 1-3, 104, 107, 108. The final two lines are adapted from William Shakespeare, *Henry VI, Part I* (1598), Act I, Scene 1, lines 2-3. All three passages are printed in Edward Bysshe, The Art of English Poetry , under the heading "Comet."

In th'
Arctick Arctic

As the Red Comet from Saturnius sent

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design below the text is dominated by two large figures and five smaller ones. A nude and youthful male lies prone on the ground—or perhaps on a bed of straw. He faces down, with his arms bent and his head resting on them. His hair is curly and a halo of fire surrounds his head. This is probably the youthful Orc. Above him, a nude female with long, flame-like hair kneels on a cloud and leans dramatically to the left. Her left leg is extended and her right bent at the knee under her torso. Her arms are extended horizontally and she holds, and apparently lifts with both hands, a cloak, blanket, or heavy drapery to uncover the youth below, at whom she is looking. She is probably Enitharmon. The five much smaller figures above may be her sons and daughters. In the left corner of the design, just below the text, we see a nude figure lying supine on a cloud with legs bent and spread, body twisted to the left. The head position and gender of this figure are uncertain; his or her posture suggests erotic exhaustion. Similar exhaustion is indicated by the nude figure to the right. This figure is probably female and also lies supine on a cloud. Her body is bent back, with her head, right arm, and right leg dangling downward. Above and to the right is another nude female, sitting or lying supine on a cloud with her upper body propped up with her bent right arm. She faces right and probably has long hair. Her right leg is extended to the right and her left leg bent at the knee. Further to the right is an embracing couple hovering in the air, with the woman on the right. They may be kissing. The nude male, facing right, has his legs spread and his right arm raised horizontally. The female, facing left, is gowned—or at least has a tail of drapery curling over her raised left leg. Her legs are spread apart. Her long hair is gathered into a bun.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude and youthful male lies prone on the ground— or perhaps on a bed of straw. He faces down, with his arms bent and his head resting on them. His hair is curly and a halo of fire surrounds his head. This is probably the youthful Orc.

Above the youthful male lying prone, a nude female with long, flame-like hair kneels on a cloud and leans dramatically to the left. Her left leg is extended, her right bent at the knee and drawn up under her torso. Her arms are extended horizontally and she holds, and apparently lifts with both hands, a cloak, blanket, or heavy drapery to uncover the youth below, at whom she is looking. She is probably Enitharmon.
Five nude figures fill the sky just below the text. These may be the sons and daughters of Enitharmon.

In the left corner of the design, just below the text, we see a nude figure lying supine on a cloud with legs bent and spread, body twisted to the left. The gender and head position of this figure are uncertain. Although difficult to explain anatomically, the head may be the odd form (with brown hair?) to the left and just below the figure's right knee. The figure's position suggests erotic exhaustion.
A nude figure, probably female, lies supine on a cloud. Her posture suggests erotic exhaustion, with her head bent back and her right arm and right leg dangling downward.

A nude female sits or lies supine on a cloud with her upper body propped up with her bent right arm. She faces right and probably has long hair. Her right leg is extended to the right and her left leg bent at the knee.
A nude male, facing right, embraces a female and perhaps kisses her. He hovers in the air, with legs spread. His right arm is raised horizontally.

A partly nude female, facing left, hovers in the air and apparently embraces—and perhaps kisses—the male to the left. Her legs are spread apart and a gown or piece of drapery curves over her left leg, forming a curling tail. Her long hair is twisted into a bun.
The youthful and nude male lies on the ground—or perhaps a bed of straw.
The large female figure, and the three smaller figures above her on the left, lie or kneel on clouds.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The text panel is shaped like, and may represent, a cloud floating in the sky.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The text is well decorated with vines, one fairly large human figure, and animals. Right of lines 8-11 of the text, a nude male seems to be falling through the air. His body is twisted dramatically at the waist, with his legs together, his head down, and his arms raised and wrapped around his head. He appears to be bald. Right of line 5 are four flying creatures. Reading left to right, these are a bird(?), a winged insect (perhaps a beetle or moth), a butterfly or moth, and a bird. Another winged creature, perhaps an insect, flies right of lines 8-9. Left and right of this creature are two vines; the vine on the right is very worm-like. A vine below line 10 includes one loop and a grain tassel on its right end. A grasshopper or locust stands on this vine, facing right. Three winged insects fly above the grain tassel. Another vine appears further to the right, with at least one leaf and three loops. Vines, or extensions of a cloud outline, extend below line 15. A bird flies on extended wings above the first word ("Then") in line 18 and a vine grows from the "h" of the next word ("Enitharmon").

component.illusobjdesc: Right of lines 8-11 of the text, a nude male seems to be falling through the air. His body is twisted dramatically at the waist, with his legs together, his head down, and his arms bent upward and wrapped around his head. He appears to be bald.
Right of line 5 of the text are four flying creatures. Reading left to right, these are a bird(?), a winged insect (perhaps a beetle or moth), a butterfly or moth, and a bird.
A winged creature, perhaps an insect such as a moth or beetle, flies right of lines 8-9 of the text.
A grasshopper or locust sits, facing right, on the vine above line 11 of the text.
Three flying insects, perhaps flies or moths, appear below "nights of" in line 10 of the text.
A bird flies on extended wings above the first word ("Then") in line 18 of the text.
Two vines appear right of lines 8-9 of the text. The vine on the right is very worm-like.
A vine with one loop and a grain tassel at its right end appears between lines 10 and 11 of the text.

An extension of a cloud outline between lines 15 and 16 of the text takes on the appearance of a vine.

lg.l: The shrill winds wake!
Till all the sons of Urizen look out and envy Los:
Sieze all the spirits of life and bind
Their warbling joys to our loud strings
Bind all the nourishing sweets of earth
To give us bliss, that we may drink the sparkling wine of Los
And let us laugh at war,
Despising toil and care.
Because the days and nights of joy. in lucky hours renew.
Arise O Orc from thy deep den.
First born of Enitharmon rise!
And we will crown thy head with garlands of the ruddy vine:
For now thou art bound:
And I may see thee in the hour of bliss, my eldest born.
The horrent Demon rose, surrounded with red stars of fire.
Whirling about in furious circles round the immortal fiend.
Then Enitharmon down descended into his red light.
And thus her voice rose to her children, the distant heavens reply.

objnote.p: This pen and ink inscription appears below the image. The first line is quoted from John Dryden's translation of Virgil, The Aeneid (1697), Book 6, line 409. The remaining lines are quoted from John Dryden's translation of the story of "Meleager and Atalanta" from Book 8 of Ovid's *Metamorphoses* , published in Dryden's *Fables Ancient and Modern* (1700), lines 316-17. Both passages are printed in Edward Bysshe, The Art of English Poetry , under the heading "Ghost."

lg.l: Forms without body and impassive air

Thin shades the sports of winds are
toss't tossed Bentley reads "sport" for "sports," and "toss'd" for "toss't" ( *Writings* volume 1, page 710).

O'er Over dreary Plains, or tread the burning coast.
Bentley reads "plains" for "Plains" ( *Writings* volume 1, page 710).

illustration.illusobjdesc: Above the text, a scaly male stands between two female angels. He stands in a slightly contrapposto posture, facing forward, legs spread. He wears a spiky a crown—or perhaps horns are growing from his head. His right arm is slightly bent, with his right hand behind his right thigh. He holds a large sword, with its point behind his left leg, in his left hand. The scales may represent armor, although they extend over his face. This may be Rintrah, as a personification of military wrath, referred to in the text on this plate. Both angels have large wings. The angel on the left has her arms folded over her chest and looks to the right. The angel on the right has her hands together, as if in prayer or supplication, and looks to the left. Both wear long gowns.

component.illusobjdesc: Above the text, a scaly male stands between two female angels. He stands in a slightly contrapposto posture, facing forward, legs spread. He wears a spiky crown—or perhaps horns are growing from his head. His right arm is slightly bent, with his right hand behind his right thigh. He holds a large sword, with its point behind his left leg, in his left hand. His mouth is slightly open. The scales may represent armor, although they extend over his face. This may be Rintrah, as a personification of military wrath, referred to in the text on this plate.
The central figure in the group of three holds a large sword in his left hand.
A gowned, female angel with long hair stands on the left of the male figure. She has large wings, looks to the right, and has her arms folded over her chest.

A gowned, female angel with long hair stands on the right of the male figure. She has large wings, looks to the left, and has her hands together as if in prayer or supplication. Her mouth is slightly open.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The text area is decorated with vegetative motifs. A vine extends in two segments above the first line and luxuriates into large leaves in the right margin. From these leaves a vine extends toward the end of line 10. A smaller mass of such vegetation fills the left margin of the text. A vine grows upward from the first letter of the first word ("Spread") of line 10; another vine grows from the last letter of "every" in the same line. A long vine extends from the first letter of "yet" in line 11, extending to the word "towards." A small vine curls from the first letter of "Arise" in line 12.

lg.l: Now comes the night of Enitharmons joy.
Who shall I call? Who shall I send?
That Woman, lovely Woman! may have dominion?
Arise O Rintrah thee I call! & Palamabron thee!
Go: tell the human race that Womans love is Sin:
That an Eternal life awaits the worms of sixty winters
In an allegorical abode where existence hath never come:
Forbid all Joy, & from her childhood shall the little female
Spread nets in every secret path.
My weary eyelids draw towards the evening. my bliss is yet but new!

objnote.p: These inscriptions appear above the image. The first line is written in pen and ink; the second line, in pencil, may have been written by a different hand; the third line is written in pen and ink by Blake.

This pen and ink inscription appears below the image. The lines are quoted from William Shakespeare, *Henry VI, Part 2* (1600), Act 5, Scene 2, lines 33-34. We have not been able to find these lines in the editions of Edward Bysshe, *The Art of English Poetry* , we have surveyed.

lg.l: O war! thou Son of Hell,
Whom angry heavens do make their minister!

illustration.illusobjdesc: The setting is an enclosed interior space with a floor and a stone back wall. A fireplace with a grate and an arched top is at the center of the back wall and of the composition. A coal fire burns on the grate. Above is a large cooking pot with a handle suspended from the top of the fireplace by a rod, possibly with a hook at its lower end. Clouds of smoke or steam billow above the pot. In the foreground are three figures. On the left is a gowned woman, facing right and in an extremely contracted posture. She sits or squats on the floor with her legs drawn up to her chest and her right arm wrapped around her right knee. Her head is down between her knees; her long hair cascades to the ground. The gowned woman on the right sits in a chair. Her prominent knees are drawn up toward her chest, with legs crossed. Her arms are apparently also crossed, with her left hand near her right breast and her right hand near her left breast. She wears a necklace of beads and faces up with a worried or pained expression, perhaps looking at the pot. Below the woman in the chair is a male child, nude, rigid, and lying supine on a cloth spread on the floor. His eyes are closed and he is probably dead. His hair may be curly. Some interpreters have described this design as a scene of famine, including the contemplation of cannibalism by the woman above the child's corpse.

component.illusobjdesc: A gowned woman, facing right and in an extremely contracted posture, sits or squats on the floor with her legs drawn up to her chest and her right arm wrapped around her right knee. A gowned woman sits in a chair. Her prominent knees are drawn up toward her chest, with legs crossed. Her arms are apparently also crossed, with her left hand near her right breast and her right hand near her left breast. She wears a necklace of beads and faces up with her neck twisted to the left and with a pained or worried expression on her face. She may be looking at the pot.

Below the woman in the chair is a male child, nude, rigid, and lying supine on a green cloth spread on the floor. His eyes are closed and he is probably dead. His hair is short and curly. Some interpreters have described this design as a scene of famine, including the contemplation of cannibalism by the woman above the child's corpse.

lg.l:
Fam
ine so fierce that whats denied mans use

Even deadly Plants and herbs of
po
is'nous poisonous juice
Bentley reads "plants" for "Plants" ( *Writings* volume 1, page 710).
Will Hunger Eat— and to prolong our breath
We greedily devour our certain Death.
Dryden

objnote.p: The phrase inscribed on the wall is "LORD [H]AVE MERC[Y] ON US." The "H" of "HAVE" is hidden behind the upper arm of the figure to the left; the "Y" of "MERCY" is hidden by the raised left arm of the figure to the right.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The background of the design is composed of a brick wall with a large wooden door. A dark shadow cuts diagonally across the upper right part of the door and wall. The closed door is inscribed "LORD [H]AVE MERC[Y] ON US" with a cross below the inscription. Left of the door is a standing, and perhaps walking, figure wearing a heavy black coat. He faces left, looks down with a worried expression, and wears a large and dark bicorn hat. His left arm is at his side and he holds a large bell in his left hand. This bellman, as well as the inscription on the door (typical of quarantined houses) can be associated with the theme of plague dominating the design. Since his mouth is slightly open, he may be calling out, "Bring out your dead!" Below the bellman on the left are a man and woman. The man, wearing a gown or at least a shirt, appears against the left margin of the plate in profile, facing right and down, and perhaps holds the woman with his right arm. His hair is curly. The gowned woman sits on the ground, with her upper body propped up by the man. Her hair is long and her arms are at her side. Her face, with mouth open like her companion’s, expresses despair and perhaps pain, and the limp posture of her body indicates that she may be weak with plague. To the right, a gowned woman with long hair seems to be falling on her knees. Her arms are raised vertically as if in supplication, with the fingers of both hands spread apart. She faces up, with her head bent back and her mouth slightly open.

component.illusobjdesc: The group of four figures—a bellman and three figures with skin color and expressions of pain or despair— indicates that this is a picture of the plague. This is confirmed by the inscription on the door in the background, typical of what was written on the doors of quarantined houses during the great plague of London in 1665.

A standing, and perhaps walking, figure wears a heavy black coat. He faces left, looks down with a worried expression, and wears a large and dark bicorn hat. His left arm is at is side and he holds a large bell in his left hand. This is a bellman, tolling the time. Since his mouth is slightly open, he may be calling out, "Bring out your dead!"

A male wearing a gown or shirt sits against the left margin of the plate in profile, facing right and down, and perhaps holds the woman to the right with his right arm. His hair is short and curly and his mouth is open. His facial expression indicates pain (from disease?) and despair.

A gowned woman sits on the ground, with her upper body propped up by the man to the left. Her hair is long and her arms are at her side. Her limp posture and her face, with mouth slightly open and eyes half closed, express despair and perhaps pain.

A gowned woman with long hair seems to be falling on her knees. Her arms are raised vertically as if in supplication, with the fingers of both hands spread apart. She faces up, with her head bent back. Her mouth is slightly open.

The background of the design is composed of a brick wall with a large wooden door. The closed door is inscribed "LORD [H]AVE MERC[Y] ON US" with a cross below the inscription. A dark shadow cuts diagonally across the upper right part of the door and wall.

objnote.p: These inscriptions appear above the image. The first line is written in pen and ink; the second line, in pencil, may have been written by a different hand; the third line is written in pen and ink by Blake.

This pen and ink inscription appears below the image. The lines are quoted from William Mason, "On the Death of a Lady," lines 1-4, first published in his *Elegies* (1763). These lines are not printed in the editions of Edward Bysshe, *The Art of English Poetry* , we have surveyed, for they were published a year after the appearance of the last edition of Bysshe published before Europe a Prophecy .

lg.l:
The midnight clock has
toll'd tolled, and hark! the Bell
Of Death beats Slow!__ heard ye the note profound?
It pauses now, and now with rising knell,

Flings to the ho
llow gale its sullen sound.
Bentley reads "the sullen" for "its sullen" ( *Writings* volume 1, page 710).
Mason.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Below the text panel, shaped like a cloud, are two figures standing before billowing clouds (or possibly smoke) with darkness on the left. A gowned and elderly male with long hair and beard stands on the right facing to the left. His arms are raised horizontally, with palms outward (that is, facing to the left). His worried expression, staring eyes, and arm gesture suggest that he is afraid of some unpictured presence to the left. He may be Albion's Angel, frightened at the prospect of coming revolution. A gowned woman kneels on the ground before the old man, with right leg extended backward and left leg bent at the knee. Her body is bent forward and her head down. Her right arm is raised horizontally and she embraces the old man around his legs. Her long, curled hair cascades below her right upper arm. She may be supplicating the man for help. This may be a night scene.

lg.l: Arise O Rintrah eldest born: second to none but Orc:
O lion Rintrah raise thy fury from thy forests black;
Bring Palamabron horned priest. skipping upon the mountains:
And silent Elynittria the silver bowed queen:
Rintrah where hast thou hid thy bride!
Weeps she in desart shades?
Alas my Rintrah! bring the lovely jealous Ocalythron.
Arise my son! bring all thy brethren O thou king of fire.
Prince of the sun I see thee with thy innumerable race:
Thick as the summer stars:
But each ramping his golden mane shakes.
And thine eyes rejoice because of strength O Rintrah furious king.

Sweep
o'er overthe yellow year &c,

illustration.illusobjdesc: Grain stems grow from the lower left corner of the plate and coil upward into the large design above the text. Several vines, at least one of which bears ivy-like leaves, are intertwined with the lower reaches of the stems, below and right of the text. The stems form a large "C" curve above the text and end near the right margin in grain tassels. Two figures appear within this "C" curve. The nude female, on the left, is seen from behind; her long hair is formed into a loose bun. She hovers in the air, with her right leg extended and her left bent at the knee. Her body and head are twisted to the right. She holds in her raised right hand, and no doubt plays, a large, coiled horn or trumpet. The black spots of blight covering the grain appear to emanate from the trumpet and the one her male companion plays. He is also nude, seen from behind, and has his body twisted dramatically to the right. His left leg is extended, his right bent at the knee as he hovers in the air. He holds his coiled horn or trumpet with his left hand. Both arms are raised horizontally. His hair is curly. In this copy, his face is obscured.

Another offshoot of the vine in the right margin extends between lines 9 and 13. Three other vines, one with leaves, appear further to the left between lines 6 and 7. lg.l: Enitharmon slept,
Eighteen hundred years: Man was a Dream!
The night of Nature and their harps unstrung:
She slept in middle of her nightly song.
Eighteen hundred years, a female dream.
Shadows of men in fleeting bands upon the winds:
Divide the heavens of Europe:
Till Albions Angel smitten with his own plagues fled with his bands
The cloud bears hard on Albions shore:
Fill'd with immortal demons of futurity:
In council gather the smitten Angels of Albion
The cloud bears hard upon the council house: down rushing
On the heads of Albions Angels.
One hour they lay buried beneath the ruins of that hall;
But as the stars rise from the salt lake they arise in pain,
In troubled mists o'erclouded by the terrors of strugling times,

illustration.illusobjdesc: A snake extends below the text, up the left margin, and above the text. Its tail is in the lower margin; its body, in the left margin, has seven loops or coils suggesting, if not quite forming, a spiral; its head rises above the text. Its mouth is open; its tongue merges with the halo of flames surrounding its crested head. The mottled coloring on the snake's body suggests scales. This is probably the serpent-form of Orc, the spirit of revolution, although a more immediate textual context on this plate appears in line 18: "Thought chang'd the infinite to a serpent."

lg.l: (following
In thoughts perturb'd they rose from the bright ruins silent
The fiery King, who sought his ancient temple serpent-form'd
That stretches out its shady length along the Island white.
Round him roll'd his clouds of war; silent the Angel went,
Along the infinite shores of Thames to golden Verulam.
There stand the venerable porches that high-towering rear
Their oak-surrounded pillars, form'd of massy stones, uncut
With tool: stones precious: such eternal in the heavens,
Of colours twelve. few known on earth, give light in the opake.
Plac'd in the order of the stars, when the five senses whelm'd
In deluge o'er the earth-born man; then turn'd the fluxile eyes
Into two stationary orbs, concentrating all things.
The ever-varying spiral ascents to the heavens of heavens
Were bended downward: and the nostrils golden gates shut
Turn'd outward. barr'd and petrify'd against the infinite.
Thought chang'd the infinite to a serpent; that which pitieth:
To a devouring flame; and man fled from its face and hid
In forests of night: then all the eternal forests were divided
Into earths rolling in circles of space, that like an ocean
rush'd
And overwhelmed all except this finite wall of flesh.
Then was the serpent temple form'd. image of infinite
Shut up in finite revolutions, and man became an Angel;
Heaven a mighty circle turning: God a tyrant crown'd.
Now arriv'd the ancient Guardian at the southern porch.
That planted thick with trees of blackest leaf, & in a vale
Obscure, inclos'd the Stone of Night; oblique it stood, o'erhung
With purple flowers and berries red; image of that sweet south,
Once open to the heavens and elevated on the human neck,
Now overgrown with hair and coverd with a stony roof. (feet;
Downward 'tis sunk beneath th' attractive north, that round the
A raging whirlpool draws the dizzy enquirer to his grave.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A gowned male sits on a throne-like chair, the chair in turn resting on a cloud. He faces forward and wears the triple-crown of a Pope. His face, however, may be a caricature of George III. He holds on his lap an open book. Large, bat- like wings extend from behind his arms. The back of his chair resembles the facade of a gothic church, with arches and spires right and left. His gown between his legs seems to contain embroidered pictures of perhaps two gowned and standing figures, although their representation is very unclear in this copy. Below this Pope, and below the cloud, are two female angels, right and left, with large wings. Both have long hair, are gowned, bow and look down, and have one arm extended at 45 degrees. Each holds in her extended hand a scepter or staff with a fleur-de-lis point at its lower termination. These two angels have small snake-like tails (or simply vines) projecting from their gowns at their feet.

The seated figure's gown is decorated, between his legs, with perhaps two gowned and standing figures, although their presentation in this copy is very unclear.
The seated male holds an open book on his lap.
Each angel, right and left, holds a staff or scepter with a fleur-de-lis point at its lower end.

A gowned, female angel with long hair and large wings stands on the left side of the design. She bows and looks down, with her right arm extended at 45 degrees. She holds in her right hand a staff or scepter with a fleur-de-lis point at its lower termination. A small, but perhaps snake-like, tail (or possibly just a vine) extends from the hem of her gown.

A gowned, female angel with long hair and large wings stands on the right side of the design. She bows and looks sharply down, with her left arm extended at 45 degrees. She holds in her left hand a staff or scepter with a fleur-de-lis point at its lower termination. A small, but perhaps snake-like, tail (or possibly just a vine) extends from the hem of her gown.
The wavy lines extending from the hems of the gowns worn by both angels may be snake-like tails—or simply vines.
The crowned male sits in a chair. Its back resembles the facade of a Gothic church, with arches and spires right and left.
The chair in which the male sits is placed on a cloud.

lg.l: Albions Angel rose upon the Stone of Night,
He saw Urizen on the Atlantic;
And his brazen Book.
That Kings & Priests had copied on Earth
Expanded from North to South.

objnote.p: These inscriptions appear above the image. The first line is written in pen and ink; the second line, in pencil, may have been written by a different hand; the third line is written in pen and ink by Blake.

texthead.l:
Pa p al , Superstition
The lowercase "p" in "Papal" has been partially erased. The whole word has been written over another erased word, tentatively read as "Pagan" in William Blake, The Continental Prophecies , ed. D. W. Doerrbecker (London: The William Blake Trust / The Tate Gallery, 1995), page 210.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The illustration, dominated by spider webs, extends along the right margin, extends between lines 21 and 22 of the text, and fills the bottom margin of the plate. Top right is a cluster of lines that apparently represents a web; the other webs are pictured with finer lines. At least five spiders appear on the web: right of lines 15-17 (hard to make out in this copy), right of line 20, in a dense web below the first word ("Fled") in line 21, above "wide" in line 24, and right of lines 29-32 (dangling on a single thread). What may be a sixth spider appears above "& louder" at the end of line 15. A great many insects appear in the design, although some are simply suggested by little more than dots. The larger and more identifiable insects are a winged insect right of lines 11-13, a fly or butterfly further to the right and just below the cluster of lines in the top right corner, perhaps a fly below this insect, four flies (two very small) right of lines 15-17, a large winged insect (a beetle?) right of line 21 and half-way to the right margin, a caterpillar below and to the left of this last insect, another winged fly or beetle above and to the right of the spider between lines 21 and 22, and a large fly or beetle (and a cluster of very small insects) below "he drag'd" in line 21. The landscape below the text is filled with heavy vegetation, including low plants with large leaves and a vine with one loop and two large leaves intertwined with the spider web in the lower right corner. Just to the left is a nude figure, of uncertain gender, sitting on the ground and completely covered by a fine net or web. The legs are bent at the knees and the body is twisted so that the figure faces forward. The head is bent back and she or he looks up (although the eyes may be closed). The upper body is braced up on the elbows. The hands are held together in an attitude of supplication or prayer. This figure may relate to the image of "every man bound" (line 27).

component.illusobjdesc: A nude figure, of uncertain gender, sits on the ground and is completely covered by a fine net or web. The legs are bent at the knees and the body is twisted so that the figure faces forward. The head is bent back and she or he looks up (although the eyes may be closed). The upper body is braced up on the elbows. The hands are held together in an attitude of supplication or prayer. This figure may relate to the image of "every man bound" (line 27).
The design areas in the right margin and between lines 21 and 22 of the text are dominated by spider webs.

Several insects appear in this section of the design, including a large winged insect (a beetle?) right of lines 11-13 of the text, a fly or butterfly further to the right, and a small fly below the butterfly. Dots in this area suggest other insects.
A small spider (although it has only six legs) appears above "& louder" at the end of line 15 of the text. A short thread extends upward from its abdomen.

Two clearly defined, and two very small, flying insects appear right of lines 15-17 of the text. Further to the right, a spider sits on its web (though the spider is difficult to make out in this copy).

lg.l: And the clouds & fires pale rolld round in the night of Enitharmon
Round Albions cliffs & Londons walls; still Enitharmon slept:
Rolling volumes of grey mist involve Churches, Palaces, Towers:
For Urizen unclaspd his Book: feeding his. soul with pity
The youth of England hid in gloom curse the paind heavens; compell'd
Into the deadly night to see the form of Albions Angel
Their parents brought them forth & aged ignorance preaches canting.
On a vast rock, perciev'd by those senses that are clos'd from thought:
Bleak, dark, abrupt, it stands & overshadows London city
They saw his boney feet on the rock, the flesh consum'd in flames:
They saw the Serpent temple lifted above. shadowing the Island white:
They heard the voice of Albions Angel howling in flames of Orc.
Seeking the trump of the last doom
Above the rest the howl was heard from Westminster louder & louder;
The Guardian of the secret codes forsook his ancient mansion
Driven out by the flames of Orc; his furr'd robes & false locks
Adhered and grew one with his flesh. and nerves & veins shot thro' them
With dismal torment sick hanging upon the wind; he fled
Groveling along Great George Street thro' the Park gate all the soldiers
Fled from his sight he drag'd his torments to the wilderness.
Thus was the howl thro Europe!
For Orc rejoic'd to hear the howling shadows
But Palamabron. shot his lightnings trenching down his wide back
And Rintrah hung with all his legions in the nether deep!
Enitharmon laugh'd in her sleep to see (O womans triumph)
Every house a den. every man bound; the shadows are filld
With spectres. and the windows wove over with curses of iron.
Over the doors Thou shalt not. & over the chimneys Fear is written:
With bands of iron round their necks, fasten'd into the walls.
The citizens: in leaden gyves the inhabitants of suburbs
Walk heavy: soft and bent are the bones of villagers
Between the clouds of Urizen the flames of Orc roll heavy
Around the limbs of Albions Guardian, his flesh consuming.
Howlings & hissings. shrieks & groans. & voices of despair
Arise around him in the cloudy
Heavens of Albion, Furious
