objnote.p: This pen and ink inscription appears below the image. The lines are quoted from John Dryden's opera libretto, *King Arthur* (1691), Act 3, lines 329, 330, 332, 333. These lines are printed in Edward Bysshe, *The Art of English Poetry* , under the heading "Dungeon."

lg.l: Them to a Dungeons depth I sent, fast bound,

Where
stow'd stowedwith snakes and adders now they lodge,

The rats brush
oer overtheir faces with their tails,

And croaking Paddocks crawl upon thier limbs.
"thier": i.e., presumably, a slip for "their". Bentley reads "their" for "thier" ( *Writings* volume 1, page 711).
Dryden.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The setting is a stone prison cell with stone stairs rising on the right. A prisoner, lower left, has shackles on both ankles; the shackles are in turn attached to the stone floor with two heavy chains. The prisoner is a nude male with curly hair who sits on a stone ledge. His prominent knees are drawn up to his chest and his legs crossed at the ankles. His neck is twisted to the right; his head is back and he seems to look up at the figure on the right. His arms are bent at the elbows with his hands raised, palms facing the viewer and fingers spread apart. His gestures and open eye indicate fear and perhaps pain. We see the male figure on the right from behind as he ascends the stairs (right leg extended backwards, left leg bent forward). Except for what may be a belt around his waist, he is apparently nude. His mottled skin suggests disease. His hair is curly. His right arm is at his side and he holds a large key by its ring in his right hand. This last object identifies him as a jailor.

lg.l: The red limb'd Angel siez'd - in horror and torment;
The Trump of the last doom; but he could not blow the iron tube!
Thrice he assay'd presumptuous to awake the dead to Judgment.
A mighty Spirit leap'd from the land of Albion,
Nam'd Newton; he siez'd the Trump, & blow'd the enormous blast!
Yellow as leaves of Autumn the myriads of Angelic hosts.
Fell thro' the wintry skies seeking their graves;
Rattling their hollow bones in howling and lamentation.
Then Enitharmon woke nor knew that she had slept
And eighteen hundred years were fled
As if they had not been
She calld her sons & daughters
To the sports of night,
Within her crystal house;
And thus her song proceeds.
Arise Ethinthus! tho' the earth-worm call;
Let him call in vain!
Till the night of holy shadows
And human solitude is past!

objnote.p: These inscriptions appear above the image. The first line is written in pen and ink; the second line, in pencil, may have been written by a different hand; the third line is written in pen and ink by Blake.

This pen and ink inscription appears below the image. The lines are adapted from John Fletcher (and possibly William Shakespeare), The Two Noble Kinsmen (1634), Act 2, Scene 2, lines 40-45. We have not been able to find these lines in the editions of Edward Bysshe, The Art of English Poetry , we have surveyed.

lg.l:
This is all
our myworld __
we Ishall nothing know

Nothing hear, but the Clock that tells
our mywoes, "Clock": there may be a slip of the pen or a partly overwritten letter at the end of the word.

The vine shall grow, but
we Ishall never see it,
Summer shall come, and with her all delights,
But dead cold winter still inhabit here.

lg.l: Ethinthus queen of waters, how thou shinest in the sky:
My daughter how do I rejoice! for thy children flock around
Like the gay fishes on the wave, when the cold moon drinks the dew.
Ethinthus! thou art sweet as comforts to my fainting soul:
For now thy waters warble round the feet of Enitharmon.
Manathu-Varcyon! I behold thee flaming in my halls,
Light of thy mothers soul! I see thy lovely eagles round:
Thy golden wings are my delight. & thy flames of soft delusion.
Where is my lureing bird of Eden! Leutha silent love!
Leutha. the many colourd bow delights upon thy wings:
Soft soul of flowers Leutha!
Sweet smiling pestilence! I see thy blushing light:
Thy daughters many changing,
Revolve like sweet perfumes ascending O Leutha silken queen!
Where is the youthful Antamon. prince of the pearly dew.
O Antamon, why wilt thou leave thy mother Enitharmon?
Alone I see thee. crystal form.
Floting upon the bosomd air:
With lineaments of gratified desire.
My Antamon the seven churches of Leutha seek thy love.
I hear the soft Oothoon in Enitharmons tents
Why wilt thou give up womans secrecy my melancholy child?
Between two moments bliss is ripe
O Theotormon robb'd of joy, I see thy salt tears flow
Down the steps of my crystal house.
Sotha & Thiralatha: secret dwellers of dreamful caves.
Arise and please the horrent fiend with your melodious songs.
Still all your thunders golden hoofd, & bind your horses black
Orc! smile upon my children!
Smile son of my afflictions,
Arise O Orc and give our mountains joy of thy red light.

She ceas'd, for All were forth at sport beneath the solemn moon Line 33, as originally written, contained these words, "and all went forth to sport," which were changed in the copper to "for All were forth at sport."
Waking the stars of Urizen with their immortal songs.
That nature felt thro' all her pores the enormous revelry.
Till morning ope'd the eastern gate. Line 36, as originally written, ended with "and the angel trumpet blew!" These five words were erased from the copper plate.
Then every one fled to his station. & Enitharmon wept.
But terrible Orc, when he beheld the morning in the east,

illustration.illusobjdesc: Below the text, a nude, muscular male with curly hair stands with legs spread apart, his genitals obscured by what may be semi-opaque drapery of some sort. His left leg is extended to the right, with his left foot on the ground. His right leg is bent at the knee with his foot on one of at least two stone steps. He may be striding to the left. His body faces forward, but his head is turned to the right. His expression is fearful or pained. He may be looking at the flames forming the background of the design or at the young girl whose left arm he grasps with his lowered left hand. Perhaps the man is her father, attempting to rescue the child from the flames. She wears a gown and has long hair. We see her from behind; her right arm is drawn back and raised at 135 degrees. Her left leg is extended backward; she may be striding to the left. The nude male carries, over his right shoulder, the limp body of a gowned woman—perhaps the child's mother. The man's right arm is raised, bent at the elbow, and embraces the woman around the waist. Her left arm and long hair dangle down toward the man's right knee. Her gown, and presumably her legs, dangle behind the man's spread legs. She may be dead or dying. Lower left, on top of the steps, is a fluted and broken pillar.

lg.l: Shot from the heights of Enitharmon;
And in the vineyards of red France appear'd the light of his fury.
The sun glow'd fiery red!
The furious terrors flew around!
On golden chariots raging, with red wheels dropping with blood;
The Lions lash their wrathful tails!
The Tigers couch upon the prey & suck the ruddy tide;
And Enitharmon groans & cries in anguish and dismay.
Then Los arose his head he reard in snaky thunders clad:
And with a cry that shook all nature to the utmost pole,
Call'd all his sons to the strife of blood.
